resources.string:
Newton's second law
F = m.a
where F = net force applied
m = mass
a = acceleration


Friction Force
Ffriction <= µFnorm
where µ is the coefficient of friction and it depends on type of material.
Fnorm is the reaction of the surface to the object because of its weight. Generally Fnorm = m.g

Relative Motion
Vrelative=Vobject - Vobserver

Horizontal Motion
X=V.t
where X = distance

Vertical Motion
V = Vit + gt
where g = acceleration due to gravity -9.8m/s2
X = Vit + 1/2g.t2

Work
Unit of Work is kg.m2/s2, also known as joule.
1 joule = 1N.1m
Work = Force.Distance

Power
Power = Work/time interval.
Unit of power is watt.
1 joule/s = 1 watt.

Energy
Mechanical Energy = Potential Energy + Kinetic Energy.

Potential Energy
Ep = m.g.h
where h = height.
In case of a spring. Ep = 1/2.k.x2
where k is the spring constant.

Kinetic Energy
EK=1/2m.v2

Momentum
Momentum = Mass * Velocity

Impulse
Impulse = Force. Time interval
Impulse = change in momentum

Conservation of Momentum
Pinitial=Pfinal
m1v1 = m2v2

Tangential Speed(Linear Speed)
VA = 2πr/T
where VA is the tangential speed and T is the time period for one revolution.

Frequency
Frequency is the inverse of the time period.
f = 1/T
so, VA = 2πrf

Angular Speed
ω = 2π/T = 2πf

Angular Acceleration
αcentripetal = -4π2r/T2
αcentripetal = -ω2r = VA2/r

Centripetal Force
Fc = -m4π2r/T2 = mVA2/r

Torque
τ = Applied Force * Distance * sinӨ
where Distance is the shortest distance between the point of application of force and the fixed axis; Ө is the angle of application of force.

Reflection of lightangle of incident ray = angle of reflection
θ1 = θ2

Moving plane mirror
If the mirror moves with a velocity of V, then image of the object moves with the velocity of 2V.
If the object moves with a velocity V then image also moves with V but in the opposite direction.

Mirror equations of curved mirrors
1/f = 1/Do + 1/Di

Refractive Index
na = Speed of light in vacuum/speed of light in a medium = c/Va

Snell's Law
n1.Sinθ1 = n2.Sinθ2
n1/n2 = v1/v2
where, θ1 angle of the incident ray and θ2 is the angle of the refracted ray, n1, n2 are refractive indices of the mediums and v1 and v2 are velocity of light in the mediums.

Critical angle and total reflection
sin θc = n1/n2
Rays coming with an angle larger than θc make total reflection.

Apparent depth and Real depth
Da = Dr * nobserver/nobject
where, Da is the apparent depth, Dr = real depth, nobserver = refractive index of the medium of the observer and nobject is the refractive index of the medium of the object

Temperature
C/100 = (F-32)/180 = (K-273)/100

Heat
Q = m.c.∆T
where c Q is the heat transfered, m is the mass of the body, c is the specific heat capacity and ∆T is the change in temperature

Heat transfer
Qgained=Qlost
m1c1∆T1=m2c2∆T2

Thermal expansion
∆V=V0.α. ∆T
where ∆V is the change in the volume, α is the coefficient of thermal expansion and ∆T is the change in temperature of the matter

Linear expansion
∆L=L0.α. ∆T

Area expansion
∆S=S0.2α. ∆T

Volume expansion
∆V=V0.3α. ∆T

Coulumb's Law
F = k(q1q2)/d2
where q1 is the amount of charge on object 1, q2 is the amount of charge on object 2, k is te proportionality constant and d is the distance between two objects

Electric Field
E = F/q = kq/r2
Electric field is a vector quantity and it decreases with the increasing distance. k = 9 X 109N.m2/C2

Force acting on a charged particle in Electric field
E = F/q
where F is the force acting on the particle with charge q in an electric field E.If q is positive then F=+E.q and directions of Force and Electric Field are same. If q is negative then F =-E.q and directions of Force and Electric Field are opposite.

Electric Potential Energy
Electric potential energy = k (q1.q2)/d

Electric potential
V = k.q/d
V is a scalar quantity. If q is negative then V becomes negative, or if q is positive then V becomes positive. Surfaces having equal potentials are called equipotential surfaces.

Capacitance
C = Q/V
where C is the capacitance of the conductor, Q is the amount of charge gained and V is the potential gained.

Capacitors
C = Ε.A/d

Capacitors in Parallel
Q1 = C1V
Q2 = C2V
Ceq = C1+C2C3

Capacitors in Series
C1V1 = Q
C2V2 = Q
1/Ceq = 1/C1 + 1/C2

Electric Current
I = ∆Q/∆t
where I is the current, Q is the charge and t is the time. The unit of electric current is Coulomb per second or Ampere (A).

Resistance
R=ρl/A
where ρ is the resistivity, l is the length and A is the area of the material

Ohm's Law 
V1/I1 = constant = R

Resistors in series
i = i1 = i2 = i3
V = V1 + V2 + V3
Req = R1 + R2 + R3

Resistors in parallel
i = i1 + i2 + i3
V = V1 = V2 = V3
1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

Batteries
EMF is the energy given by the battery to the unit charge when it passes from one end to the other end of the battery. We can say that, if the EMF of the closed circuit is known then EMF is directly proportional to the charge in the circuit.
W=ε.Q where Q=i.t
W=ε.i.t

Batteries in series
εeq=ε1+ε2+ε3+...+εn

Batteries in parallel
εeq=ε1=ε2=ε
1/req = 1/r1 + 1/r2...+ 1/rn

Energy
E=i2.R.t=V2/R.t

Electric power
P = V.i
P = i2.R = V2/R

Coulomb\’s Law for Magnetism
F = k m1.m2/d2
F1 = -F2
where k is the constact, m1 and m2 are the magnetic intensities of the poles and d is the distance between them.

Magnetic field
Magnetic field is a vector quantity and showed with the letter B. Unit of B is Tesla. When we calculate magnetic field of a magnet we assume that there is a 1 unit of m at the point we want to find. We find the magnetic field with following formula:
B = F/m

Magnetic Flux
We show magnetic flux with the Greek letter; Ф. We find it with following formula:
Ф=B.A.cosӨ
Where Ф is the magnetic flux and unit of Ф is Weber (Wb), B is the magnetic field and unit of B is Tesla, A is the area of the surface and unit of A is m2.

Magnetic Field around a Wire
B=2k.i/d

Magnetic Field around a Circular Wire
B = 2πk.i/r

Magnetic Field around a Solenoid
B = 4πk i.N/l
where i is the current, N is the number of loops and l is the length of the solenoid.

Force Acting on Moving Particle and Current Carrying Wire
F=B.i.l.sinß

Force Acting on Charged Particle
If the particle has charge q, velocity v and it is placed in a magnetic field having strength B force acting on this particle and ß is the agle between the velocity and magnetic field is found with following formula
F=q.v.B.sinß

Forces of Currents Carrying Wires on Each Other
F = B1.i2l = 2.k.(i1.i2.l)/d
where l is the length of the wires, d is the distance between them.

Kepler's Laws
Following are the three Kepler's laws
1.The orbit of each planet is an ellipse which has the Sun at one of its foci.
2.Each planet moves in such a way that the (imaginary) line joining it to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal times.
3.The squares of the periods of revolution of the planets about the Sun are proportional to the cubes of their mean distances from it.

Newton's law of universal gravitation
F = G.m1.m2/r2
where F is the force due to gravity, g the acceleration due to gravity, G the Universal Gravitational Constant (6.67x10-11 N.m2/kg2), m the mass and r the distance between two objects.

Acceleration due to gravity outside the Earth
g' = (re2/r2).g
where g' is the acceleration due to gravity at a radius r outside the earth in terms of the Earth's radius (re) and the acceleration due to gravity at the Earth's surface g.

Acceleration due to gravity inside the Earth
g' = (r/re)g
where r represent the radius of the point inside the earth.

Note: In both the above formulas, as expected, g' becomes equal to g when r = re.

Constants and conversion factors

1 unified atomic mass unit : 1u = 1.66 X 10-27kg or 931 MeV/c2

Proton mass : mp = 1.67 X 10-27 Kg

Neutron mass : mn = 1.67 X 10-27 Kg

Electron mass : me = 9.11 X 10-31 Kg

Magnitude of electronic charge : e = 1.60 X 10-19 C

Avagadro's number : N0 = 6.02 X 1023 mol-1

Universal gas constant : R = 8.31 J/(mol.K)

Boltzman's constant kB = 1.38 X 10-23 J/K

Speed of light : c = 3.00 X 108 m/s

Planck's constant : h = 6.63 X 10-34 J.s

Vacuum permittivity : ε0 = 8.85 X 10-12 C2/N.m2

Coulomb's law constant : 1/(4πε0) = 9.0 X 10ε9 N.m2/C2

Vacuum pemeability : α0 = 4π X 10-7 T.m/A

Magnetic constant k' = α/4π = 10-7 T.m/A

Universal gravitation constant : G = 6.67x10-11 N.(m\kg)2

Acceleration due to gravity : g = 9.8 m/s2

1 atmosphere pressure : 1 atm = 1 X 105 N/m2 = 1 X 105 Pa

1 electron volt : 1eV = 1.60 X 10-19 J.

Maxwell's Equations
Maxwell\’s four equations describe the electric and magnetic fields arising from varying distributions of electric charges and currents, and how those fields change in time.
Here are the equations:
1. Gauss' Law for electric fields:
∫E-.dA- = q/ε0
The integral of the outgoing electric field over an area enclosing a volume equals the total charge inside, in appropriate units.

2. The corresponding formula for magnetic fields:
∫B-. dA- = 0
No magnetic charge exists: no “monopoles”.

3. Faraday\’s Law of Magnetic Induction:
∮E-. dl = -d/dt (∫B-.dA-)
The first term is integrated round a closed line, usually a wire, and gives the total voltage change around the circuit, which is generated by a varying magnetic field threading through the circuit.

4. Ampere\’s Law plus Maxwell\’s displacement current:
∮B-. dl = µ0(I + d/dt(ε0 (∫E-.dA-)))
This gives the total magnetic force around a circuit in terms of the current through the circuit, plus any varying electric field through the circuit (that\’s the “displacement current”).

Electromagnetic Wave Equation
The wave equation for a plane electric wave traveling in the x direction in space is:
d2E/dx2 = 1/c2. d2E/dt2
with the same form applying to the magnetic field wave in a plane perpendicular the electric field. Both the electric field and the magnetic field are perpendicular to the direction of travel x. The symbol c represents the speed of light or other electromagnetic waves.The wave equation for electromagnetic waves arises from Maxwell's equations. The form of a plane wave solution for the electric field is:
E = Emsin(kx - ωt)
and that for magnetic field is:
B = Bmsin(kx - ωt)
To be consistent with Maxwell's equations, these solutions must be related by
Em/Bm = c
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the electric field E in the orientation where the vector product E x B is in the direction of the propagation of the wave.

Energy in Electromagnetic Waves
Electromagnetic waves carry energy as they travel through empty space. There is an energy density associated with both the electric and magnetic fields. The rate of energy transport per unit area is described by the vector:
S- = 1/µ0E-.x.B-
which is called the Poynting vector. This expression is a vector product, and since the magnetic field is perpendicular to the electric field, the magnitude can be written:
S = (1/µ0)EB
The rate of energy transport S is perpendicular to both E and B and in the direction of propagation of the wave.
A condition of the wave solution for a plane wave is Bm = Em/c so that the average intensity for a plane wave can be written:
S = (1/cµ0)Em2sin2(kx - ωt) = (1/cµ0). (Em2/2)
This makes use of the fact that the average of the square of a sinusoidal function over a whole number of periods is just 1/2.

Pressure
Average pressure Pav is defined as the normal force acting per unit area
Pav = F/A

Density
ρ = m/V
The dimensions of density are [ML–3]. Its SI unit is kg m–3.

Pascal's Law
The pressure in a fluid at rest is the same at all points if they are at the same height.
The pressure P, at depth below the surface of a liquid open to the atmosphere is greater than atmospheric pressure by an amount ρgh
P = Pa + ρgh

Archimedes' Principle
When a body is wholly or partially immersed in a fluid at rest, the fluid exerts pressure on the surface of the body in contact with the fluid. The pressure is greater on lower surfaces of the body than on the upper surfaces as pressure in a fluid increases with depth. The resultant of all the forces is an upward force called buoyant force.

Streamline flow
The mass of liquid flowing out equals the mass flowing in, holds in all cases. Therefore
ρPAPvP = ρQAQvQ
for an incompressible fluid
APvP = AQvQ
which is called the equation of continuity

Bernoulli\’s equation
As we move along a streamline the sum of the pressure (P), the kinetic energy per unit volume (v2/2) and the potential energy per unit volume (ρgh) remains a constant
 P + v2/2 + ρgh = constant

Torricelli\’s law
The speed of efflux, v1, from the side of the container is given by the application of Bernoulli\’s equation. If the container is open at the top to the atmosphere then
v1 = (2gh)1/2

Stokes Law
The frictional force — also called drag force — exerted on spherical objects with very small Reynolds numbers (e.g., very small particles) in a continuous viscous fluid.
Fd = 6πηRV
where η is the viscosity of the fluid in (in [kg m-1 s-1]), R is the radius of the spherical object and V is the particle's velocity.

Reynolds Number
Osborne Reynolds (1842-1912) observed that turbulent flow is less likely for viscous fluid flowing at low rates. He defined a dimensionless number, whose value gives one an approximate idea whether the flow would be turbulent. This number is called the Reynolds Re
Re = ρvd/η
